A **potion of oil** is a type of [potion](/wiki/Potion "Potion") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

  - [2.1 Dipping other objects](#Dipping_other_objects)
  - [2.2 Lighting oil](#Lighting_oil)
  - [2.3 Quaffing](#Quaffing)
  - [2.4 Repairing weapons](#Repairing_weapons)
  - [2.5 Squeaky boards](#Squeaky_boards)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

## Generation

Characters that start the game with an oil lamp will have potions of oil already identified in the discoveries section.

The lighting [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") found in [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") will occasionally have a potion of oil among its wares.

## Description

The potion of oil has a surprisingly wide number of applications, but is primarily intended to be fuel for [oil lamps](/wiki/Oil_lamp "Oil lamp"). This is done by [dipping](/wiki/Dip "Dip") the lamp into the potion of oil, which uses it up - if the lamp is lit and the potion is not, the potion will explode instead. [Magic lamps](/wiki/Magic_lamp "Magic lamp") and oil lamps behave the same when dipped in potions of oil.

Doing anything with a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") potion of oil may cause the oil to spill and make your fingers [slippery](/wiki/Slippery_fingers "Slippery fingers").

### Dipping other objects

Dipping a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") into a potion of oil gives the horn an "oily sheen", which identifies and uses up the potion, but has no further effects. Dipping anything into a lit potion of oil uses up the potion and will burn the dipped item(s) if possible.

### Lighting oil

You can light a potion of oil by [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") it, and snuff it out by applying it again; this also auto-identifies the potion. A lit potion of oil can be [thrown](/wiki/Throw "Throw") as an [explosive](/wiki/Explosion#Fiery_explosion "Explosion") projectile, dealing 4d4 fire damage to anything caught in the explosion.

### Quaffing

[Quaffing](/wiki/Quaff "Quaff") an unlit potion of oil only [abuses](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise") your [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") and identifies the potion; quaffing a lit potion additionally deals 3d4 fire damage (1d4 if [fire resistant](/wiki/Fire_resistant "Fire resistant")). However, if you are polymorphed into a monster that likes fire (e.g., fiery monsters such as [fire vortices](/wiki/Fire_vortex "Fire vortex") and [salamanders](/wiki/Salamander "Salamander")), you instead exercise wisdom and take no damage.

### Repairing weapons

Oil can also be used to fix [damaged](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") iron weapons; dipping a rusty or corroded weapon into a non-cursed potion of oil removes one degree of damage.

### Squeaky boards

A potion of oil can be used to untrap a [squeaky board](/wiki/Squeaky_board "Squeaky board"), similar to a [can of grease](/wiki/Can_of_grease "Can of grease").

## Strategy

Identifying a potion of oil is fairly easy, as it is the only potion that you can [apply](/wiki/Apply "Apply"), and randomly testing potions using this method is generally safe - however, doing this with a potion owned by a shop will result in you being charged a [Yendorian Fuel Tax](/wiki/Yendorian_Fuel_Tax "Yendorian Fuel Tax") along with the price for that potion.

The [scroll of fire](/wiki/Scroll_of_fire "Scroll of fire"), [spellbook of fireball](/wiki/Spellbook_of_fireball "Spellbook of fireball") and other [fireproofed](/wiki/Fireproof "Fireproof") items can potentially be identified by dipping into a lit potion of oil, but this method is ultimately a waste of a potion (as well as likely wasting whatever you tested with it) and is not recommended.

A lit potion of oil can be used to cure [sliming](/wiki/Sliming "Sliming") if thrown upward; quaffing a lit potion of oil does **not** cure sliming.

Potions of oil are useful for repairing weapons, since eroded weapons can only otherwise be repaired by reading a [scroll of enchant weapon](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_weapon "Scroll of enchant weapon") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused"), or else a [favor](/wiki/Favor "Favor") from your god.

## History

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), it was possible to indirectly identify the potion without actually applying it (and therefore avoiding payment in shops) by dropping everything else that could be applied, then hitting [a](/wiki/A "A"). If the potion was a potion of oil, the player was asked what they wanted to apply; otherwise, they would be told they have nothing that can be applied. As of [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"), the applying prompt always appears as long as the player has at least one potion in their inventory, regardless of whether it can be applied or not.

## Messages

- Ahh, a refreshing drink.

  You drank a lit potion of oil, and you are polymorphed into a monster that likes fire.

- That was smooth!

  You drank a non-cursed potion of oil.

- This tastes like castor oil.

  You drank a cursed potion of oil.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), it is possible to disarm a fire trap with a non-cursed [potion of water](/wiki/Potion_of_water "Potion of water"), similar to using a potion of oil on a squeaky board; this will also generate 1–4 potions of oil based on your [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"). Since oil can then be diluted back to water, the large number of fire traps in Gehennom offer an effective way of multiplying one's water potions.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), intelligent monsters can light potions of oil to throw at you.
